6.text: >>[Professor Paul Ekins] In order for the

7.text:
economy to go in a greener direction towards
a green economy, it requires very committed

14.text:
government action. Green economies don't happen
by themselves. Indeed, the fact that we're

19.text:
not in a green economy is largely the result
of unguided, undirected market forces. So

26.text:
government needs to take a strong lead. Markets
are very important, and a major part of our

32.text:
report is how market forces can be harnessed
to move towards a greener economy.

important time to do work of this kind, because

43.text:
the green economy is something that is clearly
important, and our work shows that. And yet,

49.text:
at a time when the economy is fragile, people
tend to move focus to shorter term issues,

56.text:
and that's fine, but actually we need to think
about the long term, even when we're in difficult

61.text:
economic times. And in fact, it's often a
good time when interest rates are low to think

66.text:
about how to channel investment towards a
green economy. And in fact, as our report

71.text:

and strengthen the recovery through green

75.text:
economy policy.

85.text:
me was some work that we did looking at invention
and innovation in green technologies in specific

91.text:
industries. And slightly alarmingly, we found
that in the automotive sector and in the aerospace

97.text:

103.text:

I think is a warning sign for the UK that,

108.text:
as the world moves in a greener direction,
we need to up our game in these key sectors

113.text:
and ensure that they're moving in a green
direction too.

150.text:
points to put across. The first is that we're
not talking about a few niches in the economy

157.text:
that you might be able to label green. We're
talking about a whole new direction for the

163.text:

greener. And I think the three core concepts

173.text:

this as to how we defined 'greener', was that

179.text:

climate, so we're talking about a low carbon

186.text:

we're talking about low levels of pollution,

193.text:
and resource security, so increasing resource
productivity and less reliance on raw materials,

202.text:
the supply of which might become insecure
in the future.
